title: Double-Line Font
content:
Could anyone point me in the direction of any freeware fonts that have the same look as the attached files. I'm looking for that retro soccer jersey/news station/toronto blue jays lettering that's typically very rounded and uses two lines to make the shape of the letter. I've looked all over on many freeware font sites to no avail, but if someone knows the name, it would make searching a lot easier. Thanks.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [bluejays1.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20120627025106/http:/typophile.com/files/bluejays1.jpg) | 25.87 KB |
| [cnn.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20120627025106/http:/typophile.com/files/cnn.gif) | 3.79 KB |
| [channel2.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20120627025106/http:/typophile.com/files/channel2.gif) | 579 bytes |
| [cctv06.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20120627025106/http:/typophile.com/files/cctv06.jpg) | 4.99 KB |
author: chris82080

comments.content:
You can check [Mike Yanega's Lined Font ID Guide](http://web.archive.org/web/20120627025106/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/LinedFontGuide02.html) to see if there's anything you like.

I'd also recommend [Street Cred](http://web.archive.org/web/20120627025106/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/larabie/street-cred/) by [Ray Larabie](http://web.archive.org/web/20120627025106/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Ray%20Larabie). It's free, so it's worth a try.

- Lex
Another one off the top of my head would be [Poster Inline](http://web.archive.org/web/20120627025106/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=UMT0000052) by Jonathan Macagba.
